The background knowledge is:
We report the first observation of a topological surface state on the (111) surface of the ternary chalcogenide TlBiSe\({}_{2}\) by angle-resolved photoemission spectroscopy.

By tuning the synchrotron radiation energy we reveal that it features an almost ideal Dirac cone with the Dirac point well isolated from bulk continuum states.

This suggests that TlBiSe\({}_{2}\) is a promising material for realizing quantum topological transport.

instruction:
The background knowledge is:
1(a).

This is similar to the well-known 3D topological insulator Bi\({}_{2}\)Se\({}_{3}\), where five atomic layers form a quintuple layer Se-Bi-Se\({}^{\prime}\)-Bi-Se, and the coupling between two quintuple layers is of the van der Waals type.

On the contrary, Tl-based materials have a 3D character because each Tl(Bi) layer is sandwiched by two Se layers with strong coupling between neighboring atomic layers.

Figure 1(b) shows the bulk and the (111) surface Brillouin zone (SBZ).Here, \(\bar{\Gamma}\) and \(\bar{M}\) are the time-reversal invariant wave vectors or the surface Kramers points.

The single crystalline samples of TlBiSe\({}_{2}\) were grown by a standard procedure using Bridgman method .

ARPES experiment was performed with synchrotron radiation in the photon energy range of 22-98 eV at the linear undulator beam line (BL1) of Hiroshima Synchrotron Radiation Center (HSRC).The photoemission spectra were acquired with a hemispherical photoelectron analyzer (VG-SCIENTA R4000) at 10 K, using linearly polarized light with the electric field vector parallel (_p_ polarization) and perpendicular (_s_ polarization) to the plane spanned by surface normal and photoelectron propagation vector.

The overall energy and angular resolutions were set at 20 meV and \(\pm 0.1^{\circ}\), respectively, which enables us to trace very steep energy dispersions.The samples were _in situ_ cleaved under the ultrahigh vacuum below \(1\times 10^{-8}\) Pa.

Figure 1(c) shows the \(k_{z}\) values versus \(k_{\parallel}\) at several photon energies from 58 to 98 eV obtained with the formula \(k_{z}=(1/\hbar)\sqrt{2m(E_{K}{\rm cos}^{2}\theta+V_{0})}\), where \(E_{K}\) and \(V_{0}\) are the photoelectron kinetic energy and inner potential.

(The same value as for Bi\({}_{2}\)Se\({}_{3}\) is used, \(V_{0}=11.7\) eV .)One can thus trace the bulk electronic states along LFL direction by tuning the photon energy [Fig.

1(c)].

Figures 2(a)-2(d) show the energy dispersion curves and momentum distribution curves (MDCs) along the lines \(\bar{\Gamma}\,\bar{M}\) and \(\bar{\Gamma}\,\bar{K}\) of the SBZ with _s_- and _p_-polarized light (_h_r_ = 58 eV).

We clearly see the _X_-shaped massless energy dispersion along both high-symmetry lines.This characteristic feature remains at the same binding energy with changing the photon energy in the range _h_r_ = 22-98 eV, Figure 1 (color online).

(a) Rhombohedral primitive cell of TlBiSe\({}_{2}\).

The equivalent hexagonal lattice of TlBiSe\({}_{2}\) with atomic layers stacked in the sequence - Tl-Se-Bi-Se-Tl.

(b) A schematic diagram of the bulk Brillouin zone (BZ) of TlBiSe\({}_{2}\) and the two-dimensional BZ of the (111) surface.

(c) \(k_{z}\) plot as a function of \(k_{\parallel}\) (see text).In going from _h_r_ = 70 to 98 eV, the whole Brillouin zone is scanned along the \(c\) axis.

Figure 2 (color online).

ARPES on TlBiSe\({}_{2}\)(111) (i) \({\bf k}_{\parallel}\) dispersion and (ii) momentum-space cuts measured with photon energy of 58 eV with _p_- and _s_-polarized light along \(\bar{\Gamma}\,\bar{M}\) (a),(c) and \(\bar{\Gamma}\,\bar{K}\) (b),(d) lines.(e) Intensity maxima of the surface state along \(\bar{\Gamma}\,\bar{K}\) line together with the result for Bi\({}_{2}\)Se\({}_{3}\) (ARPES energy dispersion for Bi\({}_{2}\)Se\({}_{3}\) is in inset).

The Dirac point is located at \(E_{B}=390\) and 400 meV for TlBiSe\({}_{2}\) which confirms its two-dimensional nature.

The surface state bands cross \(E_{F}\) and intersect at the binding energy \(E_{B}=390\) meV, corresponding to the DP.

instruction:
The background knowledge is:
The BVB energetically overlaps with the surface state below the DP and its maximum is located at \(E_{B}=540\) meV away from the zone center (at \(k_{\parallel}=0.3\) A\({}^{-1}\)) as clearly seen for the \(p\) polarization [Fig.

2(a)].

The BVB is strongly anisotropic in the \(\bar{\Gamma}\,\bar{K}\) line it lies much deeper than in the \(\bar{\Gamma}\,\bar{M}\) line.

Note that the spectral weight of the bulk conduction band (BCB) is suppressed at \(h\nu=58\) eV.However, the intensity of emission from the BCB strongly enhances at lower photon energies (\(h\nu=22\)-\(30\) eV, not shown), and the surface state signal becomes rather weak.

From the spectrum at \(h\nu=22\) eV we have inferred that the BCB minimum inside the cone is located at \(E_{B}=200\) meV.

The magnitude of the Fermi wave vector is estimated from the intensity maxima of MDCs to be \(0.105\) A\({}^{-1}\) for both \(\bar{\Gamma}\,\bar{M}\) and \(\bar{\Gamma}\,\bar{K}\) directions.This indicates that the ideal Dirac cone with an isotropic Fermi surface shape is expected on the TlBiSe\({}_{2}\)(111) surface, in contrast to the heavily warped Dirac cone in Bi\({}_{2}\)Te\({}_{3}\).

When excited with \(s\)-polarized light, the contribution of BVB is strongly suppressed with respect to the surface state along \(\bar{\Gamma}\,\bar{K}\) line as shown in Fig.

2(d), which enables us to evaluate the surface state character more precisely.

In Fig.In Fig.

2(e) we plot the energy versus \(k_{\parallel}\) of the intensity maxima for the surface state measured from the DP along \(\bar{\Gamma}\,\bar{K}\) line and compare it with our measurements on Bi\({}_{2}\)Se\({}_{3}\).

The Dirac cone is seen to be not exactly linear on TlBiSe\({}_{2}\)(111); however, it is much closer to ideally linear in TlBiSe\({}_{2}\) than in Bi\({}_{2}\)Se\({}_{3}\), especially in the local energy gap window, \(150\) meV below and \(200\) meV above the DP.The energy dispersions are slightly warped towards small \(k_{\parallel}\) approximately \(200\) meV above the DP, where the BCB is enclosed inside the cone.

The energy dispersion is steeper than in Bi\({}_{2}\)Se\({}_{3}\) the Fermi velocity is \(7.1\times 10^{5}\) m/s in TlBiSe\({}_{2}\) and \(6.6\times 10^{5}\) m/s in Bi\({}_{2}\)Se\({}_{3}\).

Also the velocity near the DP is larger in TlBiSe\({}_{2}\) (\(3.9\times 10^{5}\) m/s) than in Bi\({}_{2}\)Se\({}_{3}\) (\(2.9\times 10^{5}\) m/s).The knowledge of the 3D \(\mathbf{k}\)-space location of the bulk states is important because it determines the probability of the surface-bulk electron scattering.

To determine the \(k_{z}\) locations we performed a detailed photon energy dependence study in a wide \(k_{\parallel}\) range.

At \(h\nu=84\) eV, as illustrated in Fig.

1(c), the ARPES spectrum mainly reflects the electronic states at the \(F\) point, which projects into the \(\bar{M}\) point of the SBZ.Figure 3(a) shows the ARPES energy dispersions in the wide \(k_{\parallel}\) range along \(\bar{M}\,\bar{\Gamma}\,\bar{M}\).

The surface state at the \(\bar{\Gamma}\) points in the 1st (\(\bar{\Gamma}_{1\text{st}}\)) and 2nd (\(\bar{\Gamma}_{2\text{nd}}\)) SBZs is confirmed to be identical.

The intensity peak from the BCB moves downward as the incident photon energy increases from \(74\) eV and reaches the maximal binding energy at \(h\nu=84\) eV (\(F\) point), as shown in Fig.

3(a).3(a).

Also, the emission from the BVB comes from near the \(\bar{M}\) point at \(h\nu=84\) eV.

In order to more clearly see the band edges at \(\bar{M}\), we show in Figs.

3(b)-3(d) MDCs for three binding energies.

From these curves we determine the conduction band minimum to be at \(E_{B}=240\) meV and the valence band maximum at \(E_{B}=540\) meV.

At \(h\nu=98\) eV, Fig.

3(e), which corresponds to the emission from the \(L\) point, the intensity of the BCB vanishes.

instruction:
The background knowledge is:
As schematically summarized in Fig.

4(a), no states other than the Dirac cone near \(\bar{\Gamma}\) reside in this energy gap region (\(E_{B}=240\)-\(540\) meV).

In order to see whether the experimentally derived features of the bulk band structure are consistent with theoretical models, we have performed _ab initio_ calculations using the vasp code .The theoretical \(\mathbf{k}_{\parallel}\) projected bulk band structure calculated with experimental lattice parameters and ideal rhombohedral atomic positions is shown in Fig.

4(b), and the result for fully optimized geometry in Fig.

4(c).

The geometry optimization was performed within the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) of the density functional formalism.

The band structure is seen to be extremely sensitive to small changes in geometry.Especially strong is the effect of the Se atom position the optimization of this parameter leads to dramatic changes in the gap region Figure 4 (color online).

(a) Schematic energy diagram of surface and bulk states of TlBiSe\({}_{2}\) derived from the experimental results.

Theoretical projected bulk band structure of TlBiSe\({}_{2}\) obtained with ideal atomic positions (b) and with fully optimized geometry (c).

Lines show constant \(k_{z}\) contours.

Figure 3 (color online).Figure 3 (color online).

(a) ARPES energy dispersions for \(h\nu=84\) eV in the wide \(k_{\parallel}\) range along \(\bar{M}\,\bar{\Gamma}\,\bar{M}\) together with the momentum distribution curves at the binding energies of (b) 180, (c) 340, and (d) 620 meV (cut 1–cut 3).

(e) The experimental energy dispersion for \(h\nu=98\) eV.over the whole SBZ; in particular, it widens the indirect gap in the \(\tilde{\Gamma}\,\tilde{M}\) line between \(k_{\parallel}\approx 0.3\) A\({}^{-1}\) and \(\tilde{M}\) point and brings it close to the experimental value.

At the same time, the relative locations of the BCB minima at \(\tilde{\Gamma}\) and at \(\tilde{M}\) depend on the unit cell volume (which is known to be slightly overestimated in GGA).With the fully optimized lattice the BCB minimum is at \(\tilde{\Gamma}\) (slightly below the minimum at \(\tilde{M}\)), whereas with the experimental lattice parameters and fixed optimized fractional coordinates of the atoms the minimum is at \(\tilde{M}\).

Thus, exact knowledge of atomic positions is absolutely necessary to reproduce the experimentally observed bulk features.We have also performed calculations of surface electronic structure in slab geometry with relaxation of outermost atomic layers for Se, Tl, and Bi terminations of the surface (35-41 atomic layers).

On all the surfaces we observe both the Dirac cone and the localized trivial surface states in the gap similar to those shown in Ref.

for TlSbTe\({}_{2}\).

They have different character and different dispersion depending on the termination, and in all cases these states are well separated from bulk bands.Our experiment, however, unambiguously rules out the presence of such states on the studied surface.

The reason for that remains an open question.

In summary, our ARPES experiment of TlBiSe\({}_{2}\) has revealed three important aspects First, the surface state Dirac cone is confirmed to be present at the \(\tilde{\Gamma}\) point.

Second, the Dirac cone is practically ideal, especially near the DP, and its velocity is larger than for Bi\({}_{2}\)Se\({}_{3}\).Finally, according to both experiment and theory, there are no bulk continuum states that energetically overlap with the DP.

This means that the scattering channel from the topological surface state to the bulk continuum is suppressed.

Our experimental results favor the realization of the topological spin-polarized transport with high mobility and long spin lifetime in TlBiSe\({}_{2}\).

(e) The experimental energy dispersion for \(h\nu=98\) eV.over the whole SBZ; in particular, it widens the indirect gap in the \(\tilde{\Gamma}\,\tilde{M}\) line between \(k_{\parallel}\approx 0.3\) A\({}^{-1}\) and \(\tilde{M}\) point and brings it close to the experimental value.

At the same time, the relative locations of the BCB minima at \(\tilde{\Gamma}\) and at \(\tilde{M}\) depend on the unit cell volume (which is known to be slightly overestimated in GGA).With the fully optimized lattice the BCB minimum is at \(\tilde{\Gamma}\) (slightly below the minimum at \(\tilde{M}\)), whereas with the experimental lattice parameters and fixed optimized fractional coordinates of the atoms the minimum is at \(\tilde{M}\).

Thus, exact knowledge of atomic positions is absolutely necessary to reproduce the experimentally observed bulk features.We have also performed calculations of surface electronic structure in slab geometry with relaxation of outermost atomic layers for Se, Tl, and Bi terminations of the surface (35-41 atomic layers).

On all the surfaces we observe both the Dirac cone and the localized trivial surface states in the gap similar to those shown in Ref.

for TlSbTe\({}_{2}\).

They have different character and different dispersion depending on the termination, and in all cases these states are well separated from bulk bands.Our experiment, however, unambiguously rules out the presence of such states on the studied surface.

The reason for that remains an open question.

In summary, our ARPES experiment of TlBiSe\({}_{2}\) has revealed three important aspects First, the surface state Dirac cone is confirmed to be present at the \(\tilde{\Gamma}\) point.

Second, the Dirac cone is practically ideal, especially near the DP, and its velocity is larger than for Bi\({}_{2}\)Se\({}_{3}\).Finally, according to both experiment and theory, there are no bulk continuum states that energetically overlap with the DP.

This means that the scattering channel from the topological surface state to the bulk continuum is suppressed.

Our experimental results favor the realization of the topological spin-polarized transport with high mobility and long spin lifetime in TlBiSe\({}_{2}\).
